page.title: ORP & Redox in Water — Electron Potential

seo.title: ORP Explained: Oxidation-Reduction Potential in Water
seo.description: Understanding ORP (Oxidation-Reduction Potential): what it measures, how to interpret mV readings, and why electron availability matters for water quality.

sections.html:
Zone 2 • Bioelectric

ORP & Redox in Water

Electron Potential — Oxidizing or Reducing?

ORP measures the tendency of water to donate or accept electrons. It's an indicator of oxidation-reduction activity.

What ORP Measures

  • Positive ORP (+mV) — oxidizing tendency, accepts electrons
  • Negative ORP (-mV) — reducing tendency, donates electrons
  • Zero / neutral — balanced redox state

Most tap water is +200 to +400 mV. "Antioxidant" waters claim -100 to -400 mV.

Interpreting ORP

Factors That Raise ORP

  • Dissolved oxygen
  • Chlorine/oxidizers
  • Exposure to air
  • Time (equilibration)

Factors That Lower ORP

  • Reducing agents
  • Certain minerals (iron, sulfur)
  • Fresh from sealed container
  • Electrolysis

Practical Notes

  • ORP changes quickly with air exposure
  • Measure immediately after pouring
  • Track over time (T0, T30, T2h, T24h)
  • Compare to baseline water

items.question: Is negative ORP always good?
items.answer: Not automatically. Context matters. Fresh mineral water can have negative ORP; so can contaminated water.

items.question: Why does my ORP reading change quickly?
items.answer: ORP is sensitive to dissolved gases. Air exposure causes equilibration toward positive values.
